{{distinguish|Conservative liberalism|Libertarian conservatism}} {{about|the political philosophy|the Canadian political party|Liberal-Conservative Party}} {{Conservatism sidebar|Schools}} {{Liberalism sidebar|Related topics}} '''Liberal conservatism''' is a [[list of political ideologies|political ideology]] combining [[conservatism|conservative]] policies with [[liberalism|liberal]] stances, especially on ethical and social issues, or a brand of political conservatism strongly influenced by liberalism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parties-and-elections.eu/content.html|title=Parties and Elections in Europe|first=Wolfram|last=Nordsieck|publisher=}}</ref>
Liberal conservatism incorporates the [[classical liberalism|classical liberal]] view of minimal government intervention in the economy, according to which individuals should be free to participate in the market and generate wealth without government interference.{{sfn|McAnulla|2006|p=71}} However, individuals cannot be thoroughly depended on to act responsibly in other spheres of life, therefore liberal conservatives believe that a strong state is necessary to ensure law and order and social institutions are needed to nurture a sense of duty and responsibility to the nation.{{sfn|McAnulla|2006|p=71}} It is a political position which also supports [[civil liberties]] along with some [[Social conservatism|social conservative]] positions and is usually regarded as a [[Centre-right politics|centre-right]] ideology. In [[western Europe]], especially [[northern Europe]], liberal conservatism is the dominant form of contemporary conservatism and has also adopted some [[social liberalism|socially liberal]] positions.
==Overview, definitions and usage== As both "conservatism" and "liberalism" have had different meanings over time and across countries, the term "liberal conservatism" has been used in quite different ways. It usually contrasts with [[Aristocracy|aristocratic]] [[conservatism]], which rejects the principle of equality as something in discordance with human nature and emphasizes instead the idea of natural inequality. As conservatives in democratic countries have embraced typical liberal institutions such as the [[rule of law]], [[private property]], the [[market economy]] and [[constitution]]al [[Representative democracy|representative]] government, the liberal element of liberal conservatism became consensual among conservatives. In some countries (e.g. the United Kingdom and the United States), the term "liberal conservatism" came to be understood simply as "conservatism" in popular culture,{{sfn|Johnston|2007|p=155}} prompting some conservatives who embraced more strongly classical liberal values to call themselves "[[Libertarianism|libertarians]]" instead.<ref>Grigsby, Ellen: Analyzing Politics: An Introduction to Political Science. Cengage Learning, 2011.</ref>
Nevertheless, in the United States conservatives often combine the economic [[individualism]] of classical liberals with a [[Edmund Burke|Burkean]] form of conservatism that emphasizes the natural inequalities between men, the irrationality of human behavior as the basis for the human drive for order and stability and the rejection of natural rights as the basis for government.<ref>Grigsby, Ellen: Analyzing Politics: An Introduction to Political Science. Cengage Learning, 2011. p.106-112</ref> However, from a different perspective, [[Conservatism in the United States|American conservatism]] (a "hybrid of conservatism and classical liberalism") has exalted three tenets of Burkean conservatism, namely the diffidence toward the power of the state, the preference of liberty over equality, and patriotism while rejecting the three remaining tenets, namely loyalty to traditional institutions and hierarchies, scepticism regarding progress and elitism.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rDd5tKWT4D4C|title=The Right Nation: Why America is Different|first1=Adrian|last1=Wooldridge|first2=John|last2=Micklethwait|year=2011|publisher=Penguin Books Limited|via=Google Books}}</ref> Consequently, in the United States the term "liberal conservatism" is not used. American "[[modern liberalism in the United States|modern liberalism]]" happens to be quite different from the [[Liberalism in Europe|European brand]] and occupies the [[center-left politics|centre-left]] of the political spectrum, in contrast to many European countries where liberalism is often more associated with the [[centre-right politics|centre-right]] and [[social democracy]] makes up a substantial part of the centre-left. The opposite is true in [[Latin America]], where [[Economic liberalism|economically liberal]] conservatism is often labelled under the rubric of [[neoliberalism]] both in popular culture and academic discourse.<ref>Bethell, Leslie: The Cambridge History of Latin America: Latin America since 1930. Cambridge University Press, 1991.</ref>
For their part, in their embracement of liberal and [[free market]] principles European liberal conservatives are clearly distinguishable from those conservatives who have embraced [[national conservatism|national conservative]] views, more [[social conservatism|socially conservative]] stances and/or outright [[populism]], let alone a [[right-wing populism|right-wing populist]] posture. In much of [[central Europe|central]] and [[northwestern Europe]], especially in [[Germanic-speaking Europe|Germanic]] and traditionally [[Protestantism|Protestant]] countries, a divide between conservatives (including [[Christian democracy|Christian democrats]]) and liberals persists. On the other hand, in those countries where liberal conservative movements have more recently entered the political mainstream, such as Italy and Spain, the terms "liberal" and "conservative" may be understood as synonymous. Often this involves stressing free market economics and the belief in individual responsibility together with the defense of [[civil and political rights|civil rights]] and support for a limited [[welfare state]]. Compared to traditional [[centre-right politics]], such as those proposed by Christian democrats, liberal conservatism is less [[traditionalist conservatism|traditionalist]] and more [[Right-libertarianism|right-libertarian]] economically, favouring low taxes and minimal state intervention in the economy. In the modern European discourse, "liberal conservatism" usually encompasses centre-right political outlooks that reject at least to some extent social conservatism. This position is also associated with support for moderate forms of [[social safety net]] and environmentalism. In this sense, "liberal conservatism" has been espoused for instance by [[nordic countries|Nordic]] conservative parties (the [[Moderate Party]] in [[Sweden]], the [[Conservative Party (Norway)|Conservative Party]] in [[Norway]] and the [[National Coalition Party]] in [[Finland]]), which have seen right-wing populist parties emerge to their right and do not comprise Christian democrats who form separate parties and the British [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] under [[David Cameron]], who in an interview shortly after taking office as [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] in 2010 said that he had always described himself as a "liberal conservative".<ref>{{cite web |last=Cameron|first=David|title=I am a Liberal Conservative|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8685185.stm|publisher=BBC|accessdate=18 August 2012}}</ref> In his first speech to a Conservative Party's conference in 2006, Cameron had defined this as believing in individual freedom and [[human rights]], but being skeptical of "grand schemes to remake the world".<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/5407714.stm "Full text of David Cameron's speech to the Conservative Party conference"], BBC, October 2006</ref>
==Classical conservatism and economic liberalism== [[File:EdmundBurke1771.jpg|thumb|150px|upright|left|[[Edmund Burke]]]] Historically, in the 18th and 19th centuries "[[conservatism]]" comprised a set of principles based on concern for established [[tradition]], respect for [[authority]] and [[religious values]]. This form of [[Traditionalist conservatism|traditionalist]] or classical conservatism is often considered to be exemplified by the writings of [[Joseph de Maistre]] in the post-[[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] age. Contemporaneous "[[liberalism]]" â now recalled as [[classical liberalism]] â advocated both [[political freedom]] for individuals and a [[free market]] in the economic sphere. Ideas of this sort were promulgated by [[John Locke]], [[Montesquieu]], [[Adam Smith]], [[Jeremy Bentham]] and [[John Stuart Mill]], who are respectively remembered as the fathers of classical liberalism, the [[separation of church and state]], economic liberalism, [[utilitarianism]] and [[social liberalism]].
[[File:Alexis de tocqueville cropped.jpg|thumb|150px|upright|[[Alexis de Tocqueville]]]] According to scholar Andrew Vincent, the maxim of liberal conservatism is "economics is prior to politics".<ref name=vincent>{{cite book | last = Vincent | first = Andrew | title = Modern Political Ideologies | publisher = Wiley-Blackwell | location = Chichester, U.K. Malden, MA | year = 2009 | isbn = 978-1-4051-5495-6 |chapter=Conservatism |pages=65â66}}</ref> Others emphasize the openness of historical change and a suspicion of tyrannical majorities behind the hailing of individual liberties and traditional virtues, by authors such as [[Edmund Burke]] and [[Alexis de Tocqueville]],<ref>Lakoff, Sandoff, "Tocqueville, Burke, and the Origins of Liberal Conservatism." ''The review of politics'' '''60'''(3), pp. 435â464, 1998. {{doi|10.1017/S003467050002742X}}</ref> as the basis of current liberal conservatism as seen both in the works of [[Raymond Aron]] and [[Michael Oakeshott]] and the ideological outlook of centre-right parties. However, there is general agreement that the original liberal conservatives were those who combined conservative social attitudes with an [[Economic liberalism|economically liberal]] outlook, adapting a previous aristocratic understanding of natural inequalities between men to the rule of [[meritocracy]] â without directly criticizing privileges of birth as long as individual liberties were guaranteed. Over time, the majority of conservatives in the [[Western world]] came to adopt free market economic ideas as the [[Industrial Revolution]] progressed and the aristocracy lost its power, to the extent that such ideas are now generally considered as part of conservatism. Nonetheless, in most countries the term "liberal" is used to describe those with free market economic views. This is the case, for example, in [[continental Europe]],<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LmfAPmwE6YYC&dq=EU+left-wing+liberal+parties&source=gbs_navlinks_s|title=Europe, a Political Profile: An American Companion to European Politics - Hans Slomp - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.co.uk|pages=106â108}}</ref> Australia<ref>{{cite web|last1=Goldfarb|first1=Michael |title='Liberal? Are we talking about the same thing?'|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-10658070|accessdate=6 July 2016|work=BBC News|date=20 July 2010}}</ref> and [[Latin America]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=MacLean|first1=James|title="The Two Meanings of "Liberalism"|url=http://www.ucs.mun.ca/~jmaclean/es.liberal.html|accessdate=6 July 2016}}</ref>

The '''Balkan endemic plants''' includes a number of unique [[taxon]]s and ([[species]], [[subspecies]], [[variety (botany)|variety]] and [[form (botany)|forms]]) that are widespread in a variety of sizes [[area]] and, including [[endemic|stenoendemics]].
The next review of endemic plants on the [[Balkans]] includes all known taxa of these categories, from [[Greece|Greek]] (including [[Pindus| Pindus mountain system]]), [[Albania]], [[Kosovo]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]], [[Serbia]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]], [[Montenegro]], [[Croatia]] and [[Slovenia]]. Northeast border goes mainly along the valley of the river [[Sava]] and continues along the [[Danube]] and including most of the [[Bulgaria]], and to the southeast to the European part of [[Turkey]]. Also included [[Pannonia | Pannonian zone]] to steps areas geographical boundaries of the [[Balkans]] of the southern part of the [[Romania]].
Observed [[endemic]]s are classified in 163 [[genera]] and 52 [[family (biology)|families]].<ref>[[Polunin, Oleg]] (1987): ''Flowers of Greece and the Balkans''. {{multiple image|align=right|direction=vertical|width=200|image1=Satellite Temperatures.png|caption1=Comparison of ground-based measurements of surface temperature (blue) and satellite based records of mid-tropospheric temperature (red: [[University of Alabama in Huntsville|UAH]]; green: [[Remote Sensing Systems|RSS]]) from 1979-2009. Trends plotted since January 1982.|image2=RSS_troposphere_stratosphere_trend.png|caption2=Atmospheric temperature trends from 1979-2011 based on satellite measurements.}} '''[[Microwave sounding unit]] temperature measurements''' have been obtained from the [[troposphere]] since 1979, when they were included within NOAA [[weather satellite]]s. By comparison, the usable balloon ([[radiosonde]]) record begins in 1958 but has less geographic coverage and is less uniform. [[Satellite]]s do not measure [[temperature]]. They measure [[radiance]]s in various [[wavelength]] bands, which must then be mathematically [[Inverse problem|inverted]] to obtain [[Remote sensing#Data processing|indirect inferences]] of temperature.{{cite book |chapter=Atmospheric Soundings |title=Issues in the Integration of Research and Operational Satellite Systems for Climate Research: Part I. Science and Design |author=National Research Council (U.S.). Committee on Earth Studies |year=2000 |publisher=[[National Academy Press]] |location=Washington, D.C. |isbn=0-309-51527-0 |pages=17â24 |chapterurl=http://books.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=9963&page=17 }}{{cite journal |last=Uddstrom |first=Michael J. |year=1988 |title=Retrieval of Atmospheric Profiles from Satellite Radiance Data by Typical Shape Function Maximum a Posteriori Simultaneous Retrieval Estimators |journal=Journal of Applied Meteorology |volume=27 |issue=5 |pages=515–549 |doi=10.1175/1520-0450(1988)027<0515:ROAPFS>2.0.CO;2 |url= |accessdate= |bibcode = 1988JApMe..27..515U }} The resulting temperature profiles depend on details of the methods that are used to obtain temperatures from radiances. As a result, different groups that have analyzed the satellite data have obtained different temperature trends. Among these groups are [[Remote Sensing Systems]] (RSS) and the [[University of Alabama in Huntsville]] (UAH). The satellite series is not fully homogeneous - the record is constructed from a series of satellites with similar but not identical instrumentation. The sensors deteriorate over time, and corrections are necessary for satellite drift in orbit. Particularly large differences between reconstructed temperature series occur at the few times when there is little temporal overlap between successive satellites, making intercalibration difficult. To compare to the trend from the [[Instrumental temperature record|surface temperature record]] (approximately +0.07 Â°C/decade over the past century and +0.15-0.16 Â°C/decade since 1979) it is most appropriate to derive trends for the part of the atmosphere nearest the surface, i.e., the lower [[troposphere]]. Doing this, through January 2012: * RSS v3.3 finds a trend of +0.137 Â°C/decade. * UAH v5.4 finds a trend of +0.136 Â°C/decade. An alternative adjustment introduced by Fu ''et al.'' (2004){{cite journal |last=Fu |first=Qiang |year=2004 |title=Contribution of stratospheric cooling to satellite-inferred tropospheric temperature trends |journal=Nature |volume=429 |issue=6987 |pages=55–58 |doi=10.1038/nature02524 |url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/oa/climate/research/2005/nature02524-UW-MSU.pdf |format=PDF|accessdate= |quote= |pmid=15129277 |bibcode = 2004Natur.429...55F |display-authors=etal}} finds trends (1979â2011) of +0.14 Â°C/decade when applied to the RSS data set and +0.11 Â°C/decade when applied to the UAH data set .{{cite web |url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/sotc/upper-air/2011/13 |title= State of the Climate Upper Air Annual 2011|accessdate=2012-02-21 |work=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration }} Using the T2 channel (which include significant contributions from the [[stratosphere]], which has cooled), Mears et al. of Remote Sensing Systems (RSS) find (through January 2012) a trend of +0.082 Â°C/decade. Spencer and Christy of the University of Alabama in Huntsville (UAH), find a smaller trend of +0.046 Â°C/decade. A no longer updated analysis of Vinnikov and Grody found +0.20 Â°C/decade (1978–2005).{{cite journal |last=Vinnikov |first=Konstantin Y. |authorlink= |year=2006 |title=Temperature trends at the surface and in the troposphere |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research |volume=111 |issue= |pages=D03106 |doi=10.1029/2005JD006392 |url=http://www.atmos.umd.edu/~kostya/Pdf/VinnikovEtAlTempTrends2005JD006392.pdf |format=PDF|accessdate= |quote= |last2=Grody |first2=Norman C. |last3=Robock |first3=Alan |authorlink3=Alan Robock |last4=Stouffer |first4=Ronald J. |last5=Jones |first5=Philip D. |last6=Goldberg |first6=Mitchell D. |bibcode=2006JGRD..11103106V}} Another satellite temperature analysis is provided by NOAA/NESDIS STAR Center for Satellite Application and Research and use simultaneous nadir overpasses (SNO){{cite journal |last=Zou |first=C. |authorlink= |author2=M. Goldberg |author3=Z. Cheng |author4=N. Grody |author5=J. Sullivan |author6=C. Cao |author7=D. Tarpley |year=2006 |title=Recalibration of Microwave Sounding Unit for climate studies using simultaneous nadir overpasses |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research |volume=111 |issue= |pages=D19114 |doi=10.1029/2005JD006798 |url=http://www.agu.org/journals/ABS/2006/2005JD006798.shtml|accessdate=2010-10-07 |bibcode=2006JGRD..11119114Z}} to remove satellite intercalibration biases yielding more accurate temperature trends. The SNO analysis finds a 1979-2011 trend of +0.128 Â°C/decade for T2 channel.{{cite web |url=http://www.star.nesdis.noaa.gov/smcd/emb/mscat/mscatmain.htm |title=Microwave Sounding Calibration and Trend|author=National Environmental Satellite, Data, and Information Service |accessdate=2012-02-13 |publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] |date= December 2010 }} The satellite records have the advantage of greater spatial coverage,{{cite book|page=510|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y0iX2z48qkUC&pg=PA509&lpg=PA509&dq=infrared+wavelengths+satellite+chosen+temperature+book&source=bl&ots=0EMWLdY1XB&sig=J-iPV0mBoX-_wj8CFTgsBV84BFc&hl=en&ei=BrBBTYP0HcGC8gawsIXFAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&sqi=2&ved=0CD4Q6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=infrared%20wavelengths%20satellite%20chosen%20temperature%20book&f=false|author1=David E. Alexander |author2=Rhodes Whitmore Fairbridge |title=Encyclopedia of environmental science|accessdate=2011-01-27|year=1999|publisher=Springer|ISBN=978-0-412-74050-3}} whereas the radiosonde record is longer. There have been complaints of data problems with both records, and difficulty reconciling climate model predictions with the observed data. ==Creation of the satellite temperature record== [[File:Weighting Function.png|thumb|MSU weighting function.]] {{Main|Satellite temperature measurements}} Since 1979, [[microwave sounding unit]]s (MSUs) on [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]] polar orbiting satellites have measured the intensity of upwelling microwave radiation from atmospheric [[oxygen]]. The intensity is proportional to the temperature of broad vertical layers of the atmosphere, as demonstrated by theory and direct comparisons with atmospheric temperatures from radiosonde (balloon) profiles. Upwelling radiance is measured at different frequencies; these different frequency bands sample a different weighted range of the atmosphere.[http://www.ssmi.com/msu/img/msu_weighting_functions.png Remote Sensing Systems] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130403061135/http://www.ssmi.com/msu/img/msu_weighting_functions.png |date=2013-04-03 }} Channel 2 is broadly representative of the troposphere, albeit with a significant overlap with the lower stratosphere (the weighting function has its maximum at 350 hPa and half-power at about 40 and 800 hPa). In an attempt to remove the stratospheric influence, Spencer and Christy developed the synthetic "2LT" product by subtracting signals at different view angles; this has a maximum at about 650 hPa. However this amplifies noise,{{cite journal |last=Christy |first=John R. |authorlink= |author2=Spencer, Roy W. |author3=Lobl, Elena S. |year=1998 |title=Analysis of the Merging Procedure for the MSU Daily Temperature Time Series |journal=Journal of Climate |volume=11 |issue=8 |pages=2016–2041 |doi=10.1175/1520-0442(1998)011<2016:AOTMPF>2.0.CO;2 |url= |accessdate= |quote= |bibcode=1998JCli...11.2016.}} increases inter-satellite calibration biases and enhances surface contamination.{{cite journal |last=Fu |first=Qiang |authorlink= |author2=Johanson, Celeste M. |year=2005 |title=Satellite-Derived Vertical Dependence Of Tropical Tropospheric Temperature Trends |journal=Geophysical Research Letters |volume=32 |issue=10 |pages=L10703 |doi=10.1029/2004GL022266 |url= |accessdate= |quote= |bibcode=2005GeoRL..3210703F}} The 2LT product has gone through numerous versions as various corrections have been applied. Records have been created by merging data from nine different MSUs and AMSU data, each with peculiarities that must be calculated and removed because they can have substantial impacts on the resulting trend.[http://www.usgcrp.gov/usgcrp/seminars/960521SM.html The Satellite Temperature Records: Parts 1 and 2] May 1996 The process of constructing a temperature record from a radiance record is difficult and some of the required corrections are as large as the trend itself:{{cite web|url=http://www.climatescience.gov/Library/sap/sap1-1/finalreport/sap1-1-final-chap2.pdf|title=CCSP sap 1.1|accessdate=2011-01-15|work=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101224094945/http://climatescience.gov/Library/sap/sap1-1/finalreport/sap1-1-final-chap2.pdf|archivedate=2010-12-24|df=}} ; Diurnal sampling All the MSU instruments and to a lesser extent AMSU drift slowly from the sun-synchronous equatorial crossing time changing the local time observed by the instrument, therefore the natural diurnal cycle may be aliased into the long term trend. The diurnal sampling correction is in the order of a few hundredths Â°C/decade for TLT and TMT. ; Orbit decay All Polar orbiting satellite lose height after launch, the orbital decay is stronger during period of elevated solar activity when the enhanced ultraviolet radiation warm the upper atmosphere and increase the frictional drag over the spacecraft. The orbital decay change the instrument view angle relative to the surface and thus the observed microwave emissivity, furthermore the long term time-series is constructed by sequential merging of the inter-calibrated satellite data so that the error is summed up over time, the required correction is in the order of 0.1 Â°C/decade for TLT. ; Calibration changes Once every earth scan MSU instrument use the deep space (2.7K) and on-board warm targets to make calibration measures, however as the spacecraft drifts through the diurnal cycle the calibration target temperature may change due to varying solar shadowing effect, the correction is in the order of 0.1 Â°C/decade for TLT and TMT. One widely reported satellite temperature record, developed by [[Roy Spencer (scientist)|Roy Spencer]] and [[John Christy]] at the [[University of Alabama in Huntsville]] (UAH), is current version corrects previous errors in their analysis for orbital drift and other factors. The record comes from a succession of different satellites and problems with inter-calibration between the satellites are important, especially NOAA-9, which accounts for most of the difference between the RSS and UAH analyses.[http://www.ssmi.com/msu/msu_data_description.html Remote Sensing Systems] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121123040542/http://www.ssmi.com/msu/msu_data_description.html |date=2012-11-23 }} NOAA-11 played a significant role in a 2005 study by Mears ''et al.'' identifying an error in the diurnal correction that leads to the 40% jump in Spencer and Christy's trend from version 5.1 to 5.2.{{cite journal |last=Mears |first=Carl A. |authorlink= |author2=Wentz, Frank J. |year=2005 |title=The Effect of Diurnal Correction on Satellite-Derived Lower Tropospheric Temperature |journal=Science |volume=309 |issue=5740 |pages=1548–1551 |doi=10.1126/science.1114772 |url= |accessdate= |quote=|pmid=16141071 |bibcode = 2005Sci...309.1548M }} ==Trends from the record== {| class="wikitable" |- ! The lack of warming then seen in the records was noted.{{cite web|url=http://www.globalwarming.org/article.php?uid=167 |title=Christy and Spencer Respond to Critics; Water Vapor Still Not Resolved |accessdate= |work=Cooler Heads Coalition |date=October 1998 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070911190509/http://www.globalwarming.org/article.php?uid=167 |archivedate=2007-09-11 |df= }} A report by the [[United States National Research Council|National Research Council]] that reviewed upper air temperature trends stated: :"Data collected by satellites and balloon-borne instruments since 1979 indicate little if any warming of the low- to mid-troposphereâthe atmospheric layer extending up to about 5 miles from the Earth's surface. Climate models generally predict that temperatures should increase in the upper air as well as at the surface if increased concentrations of greenhouse gases are causing the warming."[http://books.nap.edu/catalog/9755/reconciling-observations-of-global-temperature-change?onpi_newsdoc011200= The National Academies], "Reconciling Observations of Global Temperature Change", 2000 The same panel then concluded that :"the warming trend in global-mean surface temperature observations during the past 20 years is undoubtedly real and is substantially greater than the average rate of warming during the twentieth century. The disparity between surface and upper air trends in no way invalidates the conclusion that surface temperature has been rising."{{cite book |title=Reconciling Observations of Global Temperature Change |author=Board on Atmospheric Sciences and Climate |year=2000 |publisher=National Academy Press |location=Washington, D.C. |isbn=0-309-06891-6 |pages=1–4 |chapter=Executive Summary |chapterurl=http://books.nap.edu/books/0309068916/html/2.html#pagetop }}{{cite news|first=Miguel |last=Llanos |title=Panel weighs in on global warming: Earthâs surface is warmer, they say, even if upper air isnât |url=http://www.msnbc.com/news/356875.asp?cp1=1 |work=MSNBC |publisher= |date=2000-01-13 |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060427072934/http://www.msnbc.com/news/356875.asp?cp1=1 |archivedate=2006-04-27 |df= }} In 1998 the UAH data showed a ''cooling'' of 0.05K per decade (at 3.5 km - mid to low troposphere). Wentz & Schabel at RSS in their 1998 paper showed this (along with other discrepancies) was due to the orbital decay of the NOAA satellites.{{Cite web |url=http://www.remss.com/papers/MSU_Nature_Article.pdf# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2014-01-07 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100115152656/http://www.remss.com/papers/MSU_Nature_Article.pdf# |archive-date=2010-01-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Once the orbital changes had been allowed for the data showed a 0.07K per decade ''increase'' in temperature at this level of the atmosphere. In April 2002, for example, an analysis of the satellite temperature data showed warming of only 0.04 Â°C per decade, compared with surface measurements showing 0.17 Â± 0.06 Â°C per decade.{{citation needed|date=December 2010}} Doubts had been raised as early as 2000 about the UAH analysis by the work of Prabhakara et al.,http://www.agu.org/journals/ABS/2000/2000GL011719.shtml which minimised errors due to satellite drift. They found a trend of 0.13 Â°C/decade, in reasonable agreement with surface trends. Christy ''et al.'' (2007) find that the tropical temperature trends from [[radiosondes]] matches closest with his v5.2 UAH dataset.{{cite journal |last=Christy |first=J. R. |authorlink= |author2=Norris, W. B. |author3=Spencer, R. W. |author4= Hnilo, J. J. |year=2007 |title=Tropospheric temperature change since 1979 from tropical radiosonde and satellite measurements |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research |volume=112|issue= |pages=D06102 |doi=10.1029/2005JD006881 |url= |accessdate= |quote= |bibcode=2007JGRD..11206102C}} Furthermore, they assert there is a growing discrepancy between RSS and sonde trends beginning in 1992, when the NOAA-12 satellite was launched.[http://climatesci.colorado.edu/2007/04/13/new-paper-on-the-assessment-of-tropospheric-temperature-trends-by-the-university-of-alabama-research-group/ Climate Science: Roger Pielke Sr. Research Group Weblog] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080512021321/http://climatesci.colorado.edu/2007/04/13/new-paper-on-the-assessment-of-tropospheric-temperature-trends-by-the-university-of-alabama-research-group/ |date=2008-05-12 }} This research found that the tropics were warming, from the balloon data, +0.09 (corrected to UAH) or +0.12 (corrected to RSS) or 0.05 K (from UAH MSU; Â±0.07 K room for error) a decade. The table below summarize the adjustments that have been applied to the UAH TLT dataset. {{cite web|url=http://vortex.nsstc.uah.edu/public/msu/t2lt/readme.13Sep2010|title=UAH adjustment|accessdate=2011-01-15|work=}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" |- ! UAH version !! Main adjustment !! Trend correction !! Year |- | A || Simple bias correction || || 1992 |- | B || Linear diurnal drift correction ||-0.03|| 1994 |- | C ||Removal of residual
annual cycle related to
hot target variation ||0.03 || 1997 |- | D ||Orbital decay ||0.10||1998 |- | D ||Removal of dependence
of time variations of
hot target temperature ||-0.07||1998 |- | 5.0 ||Non-linear diurnal correction ||0.008||2003 |- | 5.1 ||Tightened criteria for data acceptance ||-0.004||2004 |- | 5.2 ||Correction of diurnal drift adjustment ||0.035||2005 |- | 5.3 ||Annual cycle correction||0||2009 |- | 5.4 ||New annual cycle||0||2010 |} Another important critique of the satellite record is its shortness—adding a few years on to the record or picking a particular time frame can change the trends considerably. Likewise, even though they began with the same data, each of the major research groups has interpreted it with different results. Most notably, Mears et al. at RSS find 0.193 Â°C/decade for lower troposphere up to July 2005, compared to +0.123 Â°C/decade found by UAH for the same period. There are ongoing efforts to resolve these differences. Some believe that much of the disparity may have been resolved by the three papers in Science, 11 August 2005, which pointed out errors in the UAH 5.1 record and the radiosonde record in the tropics. ==Stratospheric temperature trends== The satellites also measure the lower stratospheric temperature{{Citation needed|date=August 2007}} and show a decline in stratospheric temperatures, interspersed by warmings related to volcanic eruptions. [[Global Warming]] theory suggests that the [[stratosphere]] should cool while the [[troposphere]] warms {{cite journal |last=Clough |first=S.A. |authorlink= |author2=M. J. Iacono|year=1995 |title=Line-by-line calculation of atmospheric fluxes and cooling rates 2. Application to carbon dioxide, ozone, methane, nitrous oxide and the halocarbons |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research |volume=100 |issue= |pages=16519–16535|doi=10.1029/95JD01386 |url=http://www.agu.org/pubs/crossref/1995/95JD01386.shtml |accessdate= |quote=|pmid=|bibcode = 1995JGR...10016519C }} However, the lower stratospheric cooling is mainly caused by the effects of [[ozone depletion]] with a possible contribution from increased stratospheric water vapor and greenhouse gases increase.{{cite journal|last=Shine |first=Keith |author2=M.S. Bourqui |author3=P.M.D. Forster |author4=S.H.E. Hare |author5=U. Langematz |author6=P. Braesicke |author7=V. Grewe |author8=M. Ponater |author9=C. Schnadt |author10=C.A. Smiths |author11=J.D. Haighs |author12=J. Austin |author13=N. Butchart |author14=D.T. Shindell |author15=W.J. Randels |author16=T. Nagashima |author17=R.W. Portmann |author18=S. Solomon |author19=D.J. Seidel |author20=J. Lanzante |author21=S. Klein |author22=V. Ramaswamy |author23=M.D. Schwarzkopf |year=2003 |title=A comparison of model-simulated trends in stratospheric temperatures |journal=Q. J. Royal Meteorol. Soc |volume=129 |issue= |pages=1565–1588 |doi=10.1256/qj.02.186 |url=http://pubs.giss.nasa.gov/docs/2003/2003_Shine_etal.pdf |accessdate=2010-02-15 |quote= |pmid= |bibcode=2003QJRMS.129.1565S |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111020164838/http://pubs.giss.nasa.gov/docs/2003/2003_Shine_etal.pdf |archivedate=2011-10-20 |df= }}[http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg1/fig8-20.htm United Nations Environment Programme] The long term cooling in the lower stratosphere occurred in two downward steps in temperature both after the transient warming related to explosive volcanic eruptions of [[El ChichÃ³n]] and [[Mount Pinatubo]], this behavior of the global stratospheric temperature has been attributed to global ozone concentration variation in the two years following volcanic eruptions.{{cite journal |last=Thompson |first=David W. J. |authorlink= |author2=Susan Solomon|year=2009 |title= Understanding Recent Stratospheric Climate Change|journal=Journal of Climate|volume=22 |issue=8|pages=1934–1943|doi=10.1175/2008JCLI2482.1 |url=http://ams.allenpress.com/perlserv/?request=get-abstract&doi=10.1175%2F2008JCLI2482.1&ct=1|accessdate=2010-02-15 |quote=|pmid=|bibcode = 2009JCli...22.1934T }} Since 1996 the trend is slightly positive{{cite journal |last=Liu |first=Quanhua |authorlink= |author2=Fuzhong Weng|year=2009 |title= Recent Stratospheric Temperature Observed from Satellite Measurements|journal=SOLA|volume=5 |issue=|pages=53–56|doi=10.2151/sola.2009-014 |url=http://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/sola/5/0/53/_pdf|accessdate=2010-02-15 |quote=|pmid=|bibcode=2009SOLA....5...53L}} due to ozone recover juxtaposed to a cooling trend of 0.1K/decade that is consistent with the predicted impact of increased greenhouse gases. ==Reconciliation of data with climate models== [[General circulation model|Climate model]]s predict that as the surface warms, so should the global troposphere. Globally, the troposphere should warm about 1.2 times more than the surface; in the tropics, the troposphere should warm about 1.5 times more than the surface. For some time the only available satellite record was the UAH version, which (with early versions of the processing [[algorithm]]) showed a global cooling trend for its first decade. Since then, a longer record and a number of corrections to the processing have revised this picture: the UAH dataset has shown an overall warming trend since 1998, though less than the RSS version. In 2001, an extensive comparison and discussion of trends from different data sources and periods was given in the [[Third Assessment Report]] of the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] (IPCC) (section 2.2.4).[http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg1/060.htm United Nations Environment Programme] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110112044011/http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg1/060.htm |date=2011-01-12 }} A detailed analysis produced by dozens of scientists as part of the US [[Climate Change Science Program]] (CCSP) identified and corrected errors in a variety of temperature observations, including the satellite data. The [https://web.archive.org/web/20070423150153/http://www.climatescience.gov/Library/sap/sap1-1/finalreport/sap1-1-final-execsum.pdf CCSP SAP 1.1 Executive Summary] states: :"Previously reported discrepancies between the amount of warming near the surface and higher in the atmosphere have been used to challenge the reliability of climate models and the reality of human induced global warming. Specifically, surface data showed substantial global-average warming, while early versions of satellite and radiosonde data showed little or no warming above the surface. This significant discrepancy no longer exists because errors in the satellite and radiosonde data have been identified and corrected. New data sets have also been developed that do not show such discrepancies." The [http://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar4/wg1/ar4-wg1-spm.pdf IPCC Fourth Assessment Report Summary for Policymakers] states: :"New analyses of balloon-borne and satellite measurements of lower- and mid-tropospheric temperature show warming rates that are similar to those of the surface temperature record and are consistent within their respective uncertainties, largely reconciling a discrepancy noted in the TAR." However, as detailed in [https://web.archive.org/web/20101224095341/http://climatescience.gov/Library/sap/sap1-1/finalreport/sap1-1-final-chap5.pdf CCSP SAP 5.1 Understanding and Reconciling Differences], neither Regression models or other related techniques were reconcilable with observed data. The use of fingerprinting techniques on data yielded that "Volcanic and human-caused fingerprints were not consistently identifiable in observed patterns of lapse rate change." As such, issues with reconciling data and models remain. A potentially serious inconsistency has been identified in the tropics, the area in which tropospheric amplification should be seen. Section 1.1 of the CCSP report says: : "In the tropics, the agreement between models and observations depends on the time scale considered. For month-to-month and year-to-year variations, models and observations both show amplification (i.e., the month-to-month and year-to-year variations are larger aloft than at the surface). This is a consequence of relatively simple physics, the effects of the release of latent heat as air rises and condenses in clouds. The magnitude of this amplification is very similar in models and observations. On decadal and longer time scales, however, while almost all model simulations show greater warming aloft (reflecting the same physical processes that operate on the monthly and annual time scales), most observations show greater warming at the surface. : "These results could arise either because âreal worldâ amplification effects on short and long time scales are controlled by different physical mechanisms, and models fail to capture such behavior; or because non-climatic influences remaining in some or all of the observed tropospheric data sets lead to biased long-term trends; or a combination of these factors. The new evidence in this Report favors the second explanation." The lower troposphere trend derived from UAH satellites (+0.128 Â°C/decade) is currently lower than both the GISS and Hadley Centre surface station network trends (+0.161 and +0.160 Â°C/decade respectively), while the RSS trend (+0.158 Â°C/decade) is similar. However, the expected trend in the lower troposphere, given the surface data, would be around 0.194 Â°C/decade, making the UAH and RSS trends 66% and 81% of the expected value respectively. ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://hadobs.metoffice.com/hadat/images/update_images/tropical_upper_air.png A graph comparing of the surface, balloon and satellite records] [https://web.archive.org/web/20070928025821/http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/research/hadleycentre/CR_data/Monthly/upper_air_temps.gif (2007 archive)] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20101229171443/http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/climatechange/science/monitoring/hadat.html HadAT radiosonde temperature graphs] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070203081058/http://www.climatescience.gov/Library/sap/sap1-1/finalreport/default.htm Temperature Trends in the Lower Atmosphere: Steps for Understanding and Reconciling Differences] CCSP Synthesis and Assessment Product 1.1 *[https://archive.is/20130104194031/http://spacescience.spaceref.com/newhome/headlines/notebook/essd13aug98_1.htm Measuring the Temperature of Earth From Space] NASA news *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100117031411/http://science.nasa.gov/newhome/headlines/essd12jan99_1.htm Scientists Present 1998 Earth-Temperature Trends] NASA: Updated 20-year temperature record unveiled at 1999 AMS Meeting *[http://cdiac.esd.ornl.gov/trends/temp/angell/angell.html Angell radiosonde record] {{Global warming}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Msu Temperature Measurements}} [[Category:Climate change science]] [[Category:Satellite meteorology and remote sensing]] [[es:Mediciones de temperatura por satÃ©lite]]

Located at Skylab, one of Genevaâs main high-tech hubs, it has lately expanded into the development and manufacturing of "E-Straps" operated with a mobile application.<ref name="wareable">{{Cite news|url=https://www.swissmadesoftware.org/en/companies/manufacture-modules-et-technologies-sarl/home.html|title=Manufacture Modules et Technologies Sarl|last=|first=|date=February 27, 2015|work=Swissmade Software|access-date=|via=|author=Swissmade Software|accessdate=February 27, 2015}}</ref> The company offers firmware, a cloud, manufacturing, service and over-the-air facilities for upgrades. The company also offers its own apps, which bear the label âSwiss Made softwareâ.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.worldtempus.com/article/industry-news/mmt-swiss-connect-anything-apple-can-do-2456126|title=MMT Swiss Connect Anything Apple can doâ¦|last=|first=|date=September 8, 2016|website=WorldTempus|publisher=|access-date=September 8, 2016}}</ref>
In July 2016, Union Horlogere Holding and MMT have been spun-out of the FrÃ©dÃ©rique Constant Group.<ref name="Hodinkee">{{Cite news |title= MMT Spins Off From Frederique Constant |date=September 7, 2016 |work= Hodinkee |author=Stephen Pulvirent |url= http://www.hodinkee.com/articles/mmt-spin-off-independent-company |accessdate = September 7, 2016 }}</ref>
Philippe Fraboulet is the new CEO of MMT Swiss Connect.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hodinkee.com/articles/mmt-spin-off-independent-company|title=Business News MMT Spins Off From Frederique Constant As Its Own Combination Smartwatch/Software Company|last=Stephen Pulvirent|first=|date=September 8, 2016|website=Hodinkee|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>

{{Infobox distributed computing project | name = MilkyWay@home | logo = Milkyway at home logo.png | logo_size = 300px | developer = [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute]] | operating system = [[Cross-platform]] | platform = [[BOINC]] |license=[[GNU General Public License|GNU GPL]] v3<ref>[https://milkyway.cs.rpi.edu/milkyway/forum_thread.php?id=576 milkyway released under GPLv3]</ref> | status = Active | website = {{url|1=https://milkyway.cs.rpi.edu/milkyway/}} | performance = 624.337 [[FLOPS|TFLOPS]] (August 2017)<ref name="MilyWay@home Detailed Stats">{{cite web | title=MilkyWay@home: Detailed stats | author=de Zutter W | url=https://boincstats.com/en/stats/61/project/detail | publisher=boincstats.com|accessdate=2017-08-07}}</ref> | active users = 16,508 | total users = 194,514 | active hosts = 23,523 | total hosts = 411,915 | genre = [[astroinformatics]] }} '''MilkyWay@home''' is a volunteer [[distributed computing]] project in [[astrophysics]] running on the [[Berkeley Open Infrastructure for Network Computing]] (BOINC) platform. Using spare computing power from over 38,000 computers run by over 27,000 active volunteers {{As of|2011|11|lc=on}},<ref name="BOINCstats_MilyWayOverview">{{cite web | title=MilkyWay@home: Credit overview | author=de Zutter W | url=https://boincstats.com/en/stats/61/project/detail/credit | publisher=boincstats.com|accessdate=2017-09-18}}</ref> the MilkyWay@home project aims to generate accurate three-dimensional dynamic models of [[stellar streams]] in the immediate vicinity of the [[Milky Way]]. With [[SETI@home]] and [[Einstein@home]], it is the third computing project of this type that has the investigation of phenomena in interstellar space as its primary purpose. Its secondary objective is to develop and optimize algorithms for distributed computing.
== Purpose and design == [[File:Sig07-008.jpg|thumb|Starstreams from three small galaxies circling the bigger galaxy (simulation)]] MilkyWay@home is a collaboration between the [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute]]'s departments of [[Computer science|Computer Science]] and Physics, Applied Physics and Astronomy and is supported by the U.S. [[National Science Foundation]]. It is operated by a team that includes astrophysicist [[Heidi Jo Newberg]] and computer scientists [[Malik Magdon-Ismail]], [[BolesÅaw SzymaÅski]] and [[Carlos A. Varela]].
By mid-2009 the project's main astrophysical interest is in the [[Sagittarius Stream]],<ref>[http://rpi.edu/~vickej2/boincPics/sgr.flyaround.mpg Static 3D rendering of the Sagittarius stream] [https://www.webcitation.org/5i9mVIIAi Archived]</ref> a stellar stream emanating from the [[Sagittarius Dwarf Spheroidal Galaxy]] which partially penetrates the space occupied by the Milky Way and is believed{{by whom|date=April 2013}} to be in an unstable orbit around it, probably after a close encounter or collision with the Milky Way<ref>[http://rpi.edu/~vickej2/boincPics/surf.mpg Simulation of the Sagittarius stream development] by Kathryn V. Johnston at Columbia University [https://www.webcitation.org/5i9mxwi36 Archived]</ref> which subjected it to strong [[galactic tide]] forces. Mapping such interstellar streams and their dynamics with high accuracy is expected{{by whom|date=April 2013}} to provide crucial clues for understanding the structure, formation, evolution, and gravitational potential distribution of the Milky Way and similar galaxies. It could also provide insight on the [[dark matter]] issue. As the project evolves, it might turn its attention to other star streams.
Using data from the [[Sloan Digital Sky Survey]], MilkyWay@home divides starfields into wedges of about 2.5 deg. width and applies self-optimizing probabilistic separation techniques (i.e., [[evolutionary algorithm]]s) to extract the optimized tidal streams. The program then attempts to create a new, uniformly dense wedge of stars from the input wedge by removing streams of data. Each stream removed is characterized by six parameters: percent of stars in the stream; the angular position in the stripe; the three spatial components (two angles, plus the radial distance from Earth) defining the removed cylinder; and a measure of width. For each search, the server application keeps track of a population of individual stars, each of which is attached to a possible model of the Milky Way.
== Project details and statistics == MilkyWay@home has been active since 2007, and optimized client applications for [[32-bit]] and [[64-bit computing|64-bit]] operating systems became available in 2008. Its screensaver capability is limited to a revolving display of users' [[BOINC]] statistics, with no graphical component. Instead, animations of the best computer simulations are shared through YouTube.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/user/MilkywayAtHomeRPI/playlists Videos of the best-discovered computer simulations of this project.]</ref>
The work units that are sent out to clients used to require only 2â4 hours of computation on modern CPUs, however, they were scheduled for completion with a short deadline (typically, three days). By early 2010, the project routinely sent much larger units that take 15â20 hours of computation time on the average processor core, and are valid for about a week from a download. This made the project less suitable for computers that are not in operation for periods of several days, or for user accounts that do not allow BOINC to compute in the background. As of 2018, many GPU-based tasks only require less than a minute to complete on a high-end graphics card.
The project's data throughput progress has been very dynamic recently. In mid-June 2009, the project had about 24,000 registered users and about 1,100 participating teams in 149 countries and was operating at 31.7 Tera[[FLOPS]]. {{As of|2010|01|12}}, these figures were at 44,900 users and 1,590 teams in 170 countries, but average computing power had jumped to 1,382 TFlops,<ref>Data retrieved from [http://www.allprojectstats.com BOINC project statistics page]{{dead link|date=September 2017}} on June 22, 2009, and January 12, 2010, respectively</ref> which would rank MilkyWay@home second among the [[TOP500]] list of [[supercomputer]]s. MilkyWay@home is currently{{as of?|date=April 2013}} the 2nd largest distributed computing project behind [[Folding@Home]] which crossed 5,000 TFlops in 2009.
That data throughput massively outpaced new user acquisition is mostly due to the deployment of client software that uses commonly available medium and high performance [[graphics processing unit]]s (GPUs) for numerical operations in Windows and Linux environments. MilkyWay@home [[CUDA]] code for a broad range of [[Nvidia]] GPUs was first released on the project's [https://milkyway.cs.rpi.edu/milkyway/download/code_release/ code release directory] on June 11, 2009 following experimental releases in the MilkyWay@home(GPU) fork of the project. An OpenCL application for AMD Radeon GPUs is also available and currently outperforming the CPU application.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} For example, a task that requires 10 minutes using a [[Radeon HD 2000 series|Radeon HD 3850]] GPU or 5 minutes using an [[Radeon HD 4000 series|Radeon HD 4850]] GPU, requires 6 hours using one core of an AMD [[Phenom II]] processor at 2.8 GHz.{{Citation needed|date=August 2010}}
MilkyWay@home is a whitelisted [[gridcoin]] project.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gridcoin.us/Guides/whitelist.htm |title=Gridcoin's Whitelist |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website= |publisher= |access-date=November 29, 2015 |quote=}}</ref> It is the second largest manufacturer of gridcoins.
== Scientific results == Large parts of the MilkyWay@home project build on the thesis of Nathan Cole<ref>{{cite thesis |degree=Ph.D. |title=Maximum Likelihood Fitting of Tidal Streams with Application to the Sagittarius Dwarf Tidal Tails |url=http://wcl.cs.rpi.edu/papers/cole-phd-thesis.pdf |last=Cole |first=Nathan |year=2009 |publisher=Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute |accessdate=January 27, 2012}}</ref> and have been published in ''[[The Astrophysical Journal]]''.<ref>{{Citation |last=Cole |first=Nathan |last2=Newberg |first2=Heidi Jo |last3=Magdon-Ismail |first3=Malik |last10=Varela |first10=Carlos |last11=Willett |first11=Benjamin |last12=Wisniewski |first12=James |year=2008 |title=Maximum Likelihood Fitting of Tidal Streams with Application to the Sagittarius Dwarf Tidal Tails |journal=The Astrophysical Journal |volume=683 |issue=2 |pages=750â766 |url=http://wcl.cs.rpi.edu/papers/cole-apj-2008.pdf |doi=10.1086/589681|others=''et al.'' |last4=Desell |first4=Travis |last5=Dawsey |first5=Kristopher |last6=Hayashi |first6=Warren |last7=Liu |first7=Xinyang Fred |last8=Purnell |first8=Jonathan |last9=Szymanski |first9=Boleslaw |bibcode=2008ApJ...683..750C|arxiv = 0805.2121 }}</ref> Other results have been presented at several astrophysical and computing congresses.<ref>For an up-to-date list, see [https://milkyway.cs.rpi.edu/milkyway/ the project's web portal].</ref>
